Award.AwardTitle: III: Large: Collaborative Research: Moving Objects Databases for Exploration of Virtual and Real Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers at Florida International University (IIS-1213026), University of Illinois at Chicago (IIS-1213013), Brown University (IIS-1212508), and Northwestern University (IIS-1213038) are developing a high-performance model for information processing and fusion in mobile environments, providing a collaborative integration between the real and virtual worlds. This model, applicable to the fields of computational transportation and mobile sensing, enables querying and visualization of moving objects data (MOD) and their relationship to static and dynamic geospatial data. Research project addresses the issues of: balancing the processing of location-based data streams coming into MOD servers with efficient processing of visualization-related queries; determining optimal distribution of queries/tasks among multiple regional servers; maximizing the scalability of prediction techniques in terms of efficient management of objects' data and queries; modeling data uncertainty; coupling map generalization with trajectories' data reduction when zooming across different scales; resolving issues of privacy and security; and enabling semantic querying. A demonstration of the outcomes is available within the TerraFly testbed (http://TerraFly.fiu.edu) -- a public Geographic Information System (GIS) mapping engine and location-based data repository.

This work explores the novel steps towards combining the real and virtual worlds, an emerging research frontier. The virtual world is relatively well understood, but the combination of the real and virtual poses great challenges and promises transformative results with high potential payoff, including in-car navigation systems, massive fleets of mobile sensors, self-navigating vehicles, situation command, and location-based services. While advancing Computer Science, the project also leverages prior investment of, and provides direct benefit to, NSF, NASA, DoI, DoT, DHS, and other stakeholders such as the NSF EarthCube project. By improving the efficiency of spatial, temporal, and moving object data management and making these results available to constituencies via TerraFly, EarthCube and other venues, the project will produce societal benefits. This project provides a foundation for improving the quality of services in multiple applications such as disaster management, environmental monitoring, transportation, education, and logistics. The resulting technologies may serve as a base to advance research on self-navigating vehicles, robots, and mobile sensors. In particular, this work facilitates the technologies of Informed Traveler Programs, dynamic navigation, situation control, and airborne observational systems. The project provides rich educational and research opportunities for students from the collaborating institutions -- including underrepresented students. In addition, educational modules are developed, and research results will be incorporated in curriculum expansions. Further information is available at the project's website (http://CAKE.fiu.edu/MOD).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report for III-Large: Collaborative Research: Moving Objects Databases for Exploration of Virtual and Real Environments

This collaborative project conducted by a team of investigators from Florida International University, Brown University, Iowa State University, and University of Illinois at Chicago, has addressed the analysis, management, and visualization of data associated with moving objects.

Broader impacts of our work include novel computational methods in support of applications dealing with large datasets of spatio-temporal data, including environmental monitoring, vehicle tracking, traffic management, geographic information systems, and command and control of mobile sensors. Findings from this project have provided enabling methodologies for several applications of societal relevance: health care and epidemiology: the results on predicting information diffusion can be applied for predicting spreading of diseases; public safety: the findings from time-series compression and their impact on evolving spatial shapes can be used for efficient management of detecting boundaries of spreading toxic materials/gasses; transportation, particularly multi-modal navigation and crowd-sourced parking.

This research has resulted in approximately 200 publications, listed at http://cake.fiu.edu/MODPUBS/. Below are a few examples of the team's accomplishments.

The team has developed efficient algorithms for detecting motion-trends predicates (e.g., moving towards/along) and developing models for fusing uncertainty from multiple sources (GPS; roadside sensors) when tracking moving objects and, ultimately, answering continuous queries in the presence of uncertainty. Results were then extended to deal with tracking and detecting boundaries for evolving mobile shapes. Contributions also include improving route planning with lane awareness, by properly clustering the speed distribution along multi-lane road segments.

Technology has been developed for mobile applications that display traffic conditions based on aggregating reports from mobile devices of other users. Typical applications are managed by a service provider that collects detailed trajectories of individual users. A new approach for traffic-update applications has been developed based on a distributed architecture. Employing cryptographic techniques, this method enables the provider to accurately compute traffic statistics while protecting the privacy of the users' information (including position and speed).

The team has improved objects' retrieval in geospatial databases (e.g., vehicles or points of interest) near a specified location. Techniques have been developed to provide assurance of integrity and privacy protection in the execution of such searches. Specifically, the search outcomes are provably correct and complete, thus preventing the user from accepting inaccurate results stemming from data loss or malicious tampering. Also, the above proof does not reveal any additional information about the data besides the query results, thus preventing inadvertent information leaks.

The team has developed and patented algorithms for dynamic routing of transit vehicles; for availability estimation method for parking lots based on incomplete data; for emissions reduction in vehicle parking by directing vehicles to available parking spots that would most likely be attractive to the driver; for identifying interest points within a query window, with safe region around it; for efficiently and progressively computing a continuous range query to retrieve moving objects' data within a given region around the user moving along a path, with predictive and continuous production of query results without the need to repost the query as the reference point is moving.

The team has introduced an approach to data-mine the brain from a novel perspective, namely, traffic analysis. The approach considers the brain regions and the tracts that connect them as a road network, and the signals traveling between them as vehicles. Travel patterns are analyzed by a process called traffic assignment. More specifically, the brain is examined in terms of demand for communication of signals which move between neurons and brain regions, and the supply of fibers that enable, and serve the conduit for such movements. The objective of the demand/supply examination is to determine whether or not signal movement in the brain obeys some form of global design for optimum efficiency. Or, as evolution would suggest, movement patterns are emergent thusly more anarchical, with various neurons and regions acting selfishly for the purpose of local optimization, regardless of the global perspective. The former would suggest a System Optimum signal movement, whereas the latter would suggest a User Equilibrium type of movement.

The team has improved the spatio-temporal resource search algorithms in a probabilistic or competitive setting. In a resource search problem, there are spatially located static resources and a mobile agent, looking to obtain one of the resources while minimizing the cost. This model applies to many situations arising in urban transportation systems: drivers looking for street parking, taxis looking for new customers, and electric vehicles looking for charging stations. Machine-learning methods have been developed for the problems of trajectories-to-user linking, and points-of-interest (PoI) recommendations, for both a single PoI, as well as sequences of PoIs. Efficient query processing techniques have been developed for obtaining the max-diversity subset of PoIs within certain reachability constraints.


Last Modified: 01/28/2020
Modified by: Ouri Wolfson
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Outcomes Report for III-Large: Collaborative Research: Moving Objects Databases for Exploration of Virtual and Real Environments This collaborative project conducted by a team of investigators from Florida International University, Brown University, Iowa State University, and University of Illinois at Chicago, has addressed the analysis, management, and visualization of data associated with moving objects. Broader impacts of our work include novel computational methods in support of applications dealing with large datasets of spatio-temporal data, including environmental monitoring, vehicle tracking, traffic management, geographic information systems, and command and control of mobile sensors. Findings from this project have provided enabling methodologies for several applications of societal relevance: health care and epidemiology: the results on predicting information diffusion can be applied for predicting spreading of diseases; public safety: the findings from time-series compression and their impact on evolving spatial shapes can be used for efficient management of detecting boundaries of spreading toxic materials/gasses; transportation, particularly multi-modal navigation and crowd-sourced parking.
